author: @KS-ic5tc
text: I got my Google Data Analytics Certificate in April this year. I agreed with panelists that this certificate is a great starting point if you want to pursue a career in data analytics, but unlike panelists here, it took me about 8 months to finish the program because I was taking other courses on Coursera. I have taken Python for Everyone, SQL for Data Science, Tableau Visualization, and Wharton Business Analytics while finishing up this certificate.  I was a Marketing Associate and have been wanting to switch my career to Data Analytics. I started looking for a new job in data analytics in May after getting my certificate. I applied for 80 jobs over 5 weeks, got 27 rejections, interviews from 6 companies, and just landed my first job as a data analyst that I truly love.  In my personal experience, this certificate is very helpful in three ways: First, it teaches you how to approach a data analytics project in general (6 steps in this program). This comes in handy very much during the interview process because you will get asked questions like that by interviewers. Whenever I was asked this question during the interview, I felt very confident in answering.  Second, the Capstone Project can give you things to talk about during the interview when you are asked a question about the data analysis project you have done. So I would DEFINITELY recommend finishing the capstone project.  Third, upon getting this certificate, you will get one-year free access to Google's Big Interview, which I found extremely helpful in writing the resume and preparing for the interviews.  However, getting this certificate itself is not enough to get you a job. You will need to do a lot more than just this certificate such as doing more data analytics projects, getting more certificates like Python for Everyone, SQL for Data Science, etc.  I hope sharing my experience can help other people with their data analytics journey. I would love to share more if you have a sequel to this video :)  Really love all the videos and keep up the good work, Luke!!

author: @adamquek1095
text: Thanks for diving into this topic. I have completed the Google Data Analytics certificate last year just for fun, and also to see what the hype was about. I have more than 12 years of data analysis experience, and the course took me around a month to complete. Just to be clear, it was not meant to help me clinch my current job (dealing with machine learning). It's just something I'm curious about.   I do echo with the others that this is a good introduction to someone who have no previous experience in data analysis before. It is however not really set up to help clinch a data analyst job. Realistically, someone in the industry needs to be fluent in at least one programming language, and that do take a lot of time and dedication, beyond what this certificate cover. What this certification introduced in SQL and R are insufficient to carry out the daily data wrangling work that are often noisy, and the requirements of the analysis (mining and evaluation) can be ill-defined. One really need to at least complete boot camp courses on the language to get one familiar with the flow of searching through existing documentation and resources to come out with bespoke solution to noisy data. And to really stand up, it would be wise for one to have an active profile (e.g. github, collab, replit, kaggle) to showcase one's work.

author: @Voyager_AU
text: I am using Google's cerfificate as a framework on what I should learn. Becase of that, it is taking me about 5-6 months to finish it.   For example, I would do a weeks work of lessons from the cert in one day, but then focus the next several weeks taking additional courses and even a book or two focusing just on Excel and Power Query. Rinse and repeat for SQL and now I am on Power BI.  While the cert taught Tableau, instead of Power BI, I have been studying so much Excel/Power Query that Power BI felt like a natural extension. Ironically, since studying Power BI, I have come full circle and am diving more into Power Query and now DAX.  When the R course came up, I had to make a choice. Should I study R, Python or focus on portfolio projects right now? I decided to focus on portfolio projects because what I learned in Excel, SQL and Power BI will be a good enough foundation to start applying in projects. I can learn R or Python later.  So, I am running through the R course in one week get it out of the way. (I am thankful to have at least an introduction in R). On the side I am taking some Power BI and DAX courses and I just finished reading "Master Your Data with Power Query in Excel and Power BI" by Ken Puls and Miguel Escobar. (I highly recommend this book)  I have done a few projects throughout some courses but once I finished the courses I am doing right now, I will start grabbing some datasets and focus on doing my own projects to apply what I have learned.  In summary, the google's cert skims the surface. There is no way you can learn to be a data analysis with JUST the certificate. However, it does provide a good framework for further study.  Also, a shoutout to you and other YouTubers who provide invaluable help and resources for our learning journey!

text: Hey Luke. I've got my Google DA certificate a couple weeks ago and I just want to make a point on the R vs. Python discussion. They both can do the same when it comes down to manage data. Now, if you come from a different language, you feel like you are learning to program all over again. You have to switch a lot of switches in your brain and that can really hurt your programming skills in the long run.  To put it more clearly, if you know all other modern programming languages in the world, you will find R very weird so no matter how good is it for data analysis, nobody should be using it for that.
